required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison of Tapered- vs. Cylindrical-shaped Tube Cuffs Pressure Alteration With Nitrous Oxide
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of Tapered- vs. Cylindrical-shaped Tube Cuffs Pressure Alteration With Nitrous Oxide Diffusion Under General Anesthesia: an Observational Pilot Study

brief_summary.textblock:
When using nitrous oxide for general anesthesia, nitrous oxide diffusion induces intracuff hyperinflation of the endotracheal tube. Furthermore the difference among various types of cuffed endotracheal tubes in cuff pressure behavior during nitrous oxide exposure.
TaperGuard(TM) tube has been newly introduced and has tapered-shape cuff. In vitro study, the intracuff pressure of TaperGuard(TM) tube was lower than that of conventional tube with cylindrical-shaped cuff of the conventional tube(Hi-Lo(TM) tube). Therefore, this clinical study is needed to evaluate the intracuff pressure during general anesthesia with nitrous oxide exposure.

detailed_description.textblock:
During 60 minutes after anesthetic induction and intubation of the endotracheal tubes, intracuff pressures will be measured every 10 minutes with a manometer (VBM, Sulz, Germany).
After 60 minutes of general anesthesia, intracuff pressures will be maintained at around 20 cm H2O during the remaining period of the surgery.
The questionnaire for a sore throat, hoarseness, and dysphagia will be questioned at about 1, 6, and 24 hours after the surgery and the general anesthesia.

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Cohort, Time Perspective: Prospective

primary_outcome.measure: Intracuff pressure of the endotracheal tube after 1 hour with exposure to nitrous oxide
primary_outcome.time_frame: One hour after the exposure to nitrous oxide under general anesthesia

secondary_outcome.measure: Intracuff pressure of the endotracheal tubes
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 0, 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60 minutes after exposure to nitrous oxide
secondary_outcome.description: Intracuff pressures will be measured with a manometer (VBM, Sulz, Germany)

secondary_outcome.measure: Postoperative sore throat: incidence and visual analogue scale
secondary_outcome.time_frame: About 1, 6, 24 hours after termination of anesthesia
About 1, 6, 24 hours after termination of anesthesia
About 1, 6, 24 hours after termination of anesthesia

arm_group.description: Intracuff pressures of the tubes every 10 minutes, Adult patients under general anesthesia with Mallinckrodt Hi-Lo(TM) tube. Questionnaire for post-intubation complications
Intracuff pressures of the tubes every 10 minutes, Adult patients under general anesthesia with Mallinckrodt TaperGuard(TM) tube. Questionnaire for post-intubation complications

intervention.intervention_name: Intracuff pressures of the tubes every 10 minutes
intervention.description: During general anesthesia, mechanical ventilation will be maintained with Mallinckrodt Hi-Lo(TM) tube or Mallinckrodt TaperGuard(TM) tube
These will be questioned at about 1, 6, and 24 hours after general anesthesia.

study_pop.textblock: Adults patients who will undergo minor surgeries in a supine position and will need to be intubated for controlled ventilation during general anesthesia including nitrous oxide

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients who will undergo general anesthesia in a supine position
- 18~70 years old
- American society of anesthesiologists physical status 1-3
- Body mass index < 30 kg/m2
Exclusion Criteria:
- Contraindication for nitrous oxide
- Difficult airway (more than 2 attempts)
- No neutral position of patient's head
- Airway related diseases
- Short or long operation time (< 1 hour or > 3 hours)

reference.citation: Tsuboi S, Miyashita T, Yamaguchi Y, Yamamoto Y, Sakamaki K, Goto T. Technical Communication: The TaperGuard™ Endotracheal Tube Intracuff Pressure Increase Is Less Than That of the Hi-Lo™ Tube During Nitrous Oxide Exposure: A Model Trachea Study. Anesth Analg. 2013 Mar;116(3):609-12. doi: 10.1213/ANE.0b013e318279b399. Epub 2013 Feb 11.
